channel.title: GUI help
channel.description:
I decided to make my Hang Man game more sophisticated and a neater look than a DOS window. This is my first time using Swing.
The basic works:
[ul][li]User picks a category[/li] [li]Random word selected[/li] [li]Try to guess a letter or the whole word[/li][/ul]
[IMG]http://img94.imageshack.us/img94/5795/123sr.png[/img]
The big cyan rectangle represents a panel where I want to put the image of the hanging man, each part representing an attempt made.
I used paint() to draw the graphics, only got as far the head, before I noticed that the text at the bottom wasn't there.
[IMG]http://img24.imageshack.us/img24/7843/26547380.png[/img] ^^ No Text for the attempt made, but the head shows up.
[IMG]http://img689.imageshack.us/img689/7369/57975696.png[/img]
It's not a problem with that particular piece of code but (let me be cool real quick) invoking repaint() is what is causing the problems. Removing that would make it work, but I can't put graphics then. I made images: head.gif, torso.gif, leftarm.gif, etc.
But I have no idea how to put them on a GUI. Don't worry I googled and found that I can put the images into a label inside the panel. It didn't work, and also it was recommended not to use labels for these images.
Is there any way I can put graphics on the GUI for every attempt the user makes without having it mess with the text? Lead me like always; don't tell me.
[IMG]http://img5.imageshack.us/img5/641/51551003.png[/img]
If you need the whole file, feel free to ask.
Thanks.

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:15, topic:314509”]abraham, booleans would be better than chars, but even then they are too memory intensive… it’s best to use an int:

... int occupied = 0; ... occupied |= 1 << (c > 'a' ? c - 'a' : c - 'A'); ... if ((occupied & (1 << (c > 'a' ? c - 'a' : c - 'A'))) != 0) { ... } ... [/quote]thats also a very good, memory efficient idea

Read full topic

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

abraham, booleans would be better than chars, but even then they are too memory intensive… it’s best to use an int:

...
int occupied = 0;
...
occupied |= 1 << (c > 'a' ? c - 'a' : c - 'A');
...
if ((occupied & (1 << (c > 'a' ? c - 'a' : c - 'A'))) != 0) {
    ...
}
...

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:13, topic:314509”]ArrayList LoL[/quote]thats redundant and a waste of memory, the maximum amount of characters he will be storing at the same time is 26

Read full topic

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch™, post:11, topic:314509”]I’m not so worried about the hangman being displayed atm.

I’m trying to find a way to put the letter they have guessed, whether it be in the word or not, and add it to a char[] array. It’s doing it, but it removes old char. So there’s always 1 char in the array.

I’m thinking, get the last index of the array, then add the new char after that?

Any thoughts?[/quote]are you resizing the array through each addition of a character? if so, then that defeats the purpose of using a static array (since its not static)

anyways, what you should do is have a char[26], one character for each letter of the alphabet. this will reduce the execution time for your application through each addition of an incorrect/used character and also for retrieving the value of a certain character (to see if it has been used or not), since it would be O(1), rather than like O(26 / 2) (if using a list or such)

anyways, here’s pseudocode:

char[] occupied = new char[26]; for (int i = 0; i < 26; i++) { occupied[i] = -1; } byte c = Character.toLowerCase(/*user tries a character*/) - 97; //assuming you are using utf-8 if (occupied[c] == -1) { /*not in use*/ occupied[c] = c + 97; }

Read full topic

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

I’m not so worried about the hangman being displayed atm.

I’m trying to find a way to put the letter they have guessed, whether it be in the word or not, and add it to a char[] array. It’s doing it, but it removes old char. So there’s always 1 char in the array.

I’m thinking, get the last index of the array, then add the new char after that?

Any thoughts?

Read full topic

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

I’m not sure if they are the same, but it’s not for a web applet.

I’m reading and testing now.

Thanks for the quick reply.

EDIT:

Figured out that the overriding paint isn’t good because then the text won’t appear, and I’ll be better off overriding the paintComponent method.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI help
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

“But I have no idea how to put them on a GUI.
Don’t worry I googled and found that I can put the images into a label inside the panel. It didn’t work, and also it was recommended not to use labels for these images.”

Read the with ImageIO (or the getImage() method that all Applets inherit) and paint them to a Canvas.

Read full topic
